Let $A,B,C$ be three sets of cardinality $\aleph_1$. Is it true that, in any $2$-colouring of $A\times B\times C$, there must exist $A_1\subset A$, $B_1\subset B$, $C_1\subset C$, all of cardinality $\aleph_0$, such that $A_1\times B_1\times C_1$ is monochromatic?



A problem of Erd\H{o}s and Hajnal.

This was disproved by Prikry and Mills in 1978 but this seems to have been unpublished. This is reported by Todor\v{c}evi\'{c} \cite{To94} and Komj\'{a}th \cite{Ko25b}.




References


[Ko25b] P. Komj\'{a}th, The Erd\H{o}s-Hajnal Probem List. Bull. Symb. Log. (2025), 418--461.

[To94] Todor\v cevi\'c, Stevo, Some partitions of three-dimensional combinatorial cubes. J. Combin. Theory Ser. A (1994), 410--437.
